#Qatar won. #qatar2022 PR won. 

Cloaking Messi in Qatari culture at the #WorldCup2022 ‘s most climactic moment!!

Congrats ‘Sheikh’ Messi

By brother Mohammed Saqub:
“What is the significance of the symbolic gift of this black cloak from the Amir of Qatar to Lional Messi?

A number of us in the West have been fortunate to adorn something that bears a remarkable similarity to it for our graduation ceremonies.  The humble beginnings of this familiar garment find its origins further East.

Initially these ‘robes of honour’ were adorned by eminent scholars of the religious sciences. Often accompanied by the ‘mortar board' styled hat designed initially to rest  religious scripture on the 'mortar' to symbolize the primacy of Scripture over the intellect. 

Attire adopted now in many cultures to distinguish those that have excelled in their chosen discipline. 

Messi was adorned by his host today as one of the greatest to have graced the beautiful game.  It is difficult to argue against this.”

It’s like crowning someone. Nothing negative about it!

One morsel of food is all they ask for. This is the struggle many are facing in these difficult days. We invite you to open your heart and donate whatever amount you can; a small amount goes a long way.⁠

As Muslims, we should be proud to follow guidelines from Allah! There is so much wisdom behind His guidelines that we might not see, but we should still strive to trust His wisdom!
.
Some of the guidelines are:
-Lower your gaze & avoid touching the opposite sex.
-Speak professionally and formally avoiding chit chat & flirtatious talk or free-mixing.
-Don’t be alone in a secluded space with a person of the opposite sex.
-Be God-conscious in your interactions.
-Cover everything but the face and hands with opaque, modest, loose garments (for women).
-Cover at least between the naval and the knee and more according to what is considered culturally decent with loose, opaque clothing (for men).

.
.
.

Imagine a scene in the park where the sun shines brightly and the air is filled with the laughter of children. In this idyllic setting, I found myself engaged in a deeply moving conversation with a young mother.

Fatigue was etched upon her face and her weary eyes spoke volumes about the sleepless nights she had endured while caring for her two little ones.

She felt ill-equipped as a mother, longing for a sense of freedom she hadn’t anticipated before becoming a parent. She yearned for freedom from the demands of raising children, which had taken its toll on her marriage and disrupted her plans.

In a moment of unfiltered emotion, she blurted out, "I sometimes wish I never had children!"

As I gazed at the beautiful, carefree children playing before us, my heart sank 😞. I couldn't help but feel a profound sense of sadness for the limited perspective she held.

It then struck me:

Our society has undervalued the sacred role of parenthood, leading many of us to overlook the extraordinary opportunity and immeasurable returns that children bring.

This young mother had no clear or compelling vision for her family's future and so was going through the motions of parenthood without a guiding star to light her way. As a result, she found herself mired in misery, failing to grasp the immense *gift from Allah* that her family were.

We all need a vision for our families. Life is too tough without it!
[Contd. in comments]👇🏼

Muslim fathers!
You are a dad, a father, a leader, a patriarch, a provider, a protector, a shepherd, a steward of God on this earth.
Society needs you to be strong, your wife needs your leadership, your kids need your guidance, your community needs you to be purposeful, the Ummah needs you. Your family is the microcosm of the Ummah. And as leader of your family, your leadership can be exceptional IF YOU HAVE A VISION.
On Thursday 15th June at 7pm London I'm helping parents write their Islamic family vision. THE ISLAMIC FAMILY VISION BLUEPRINT is a free webinar for parents to help you craft a family vision you can get your family behind.
Join us by registering now and you will receive the FREE workbook to accompany the webinar: https://www.raisingbelievers.com/webinar

The stories of Sara, Brother Karim and Abu Laila serve as a wake-up call to Muslim parents raising children in the modern age. Too often, they find themselves in desperate situations, reaching out to me for help when it feels too late.

❗️Sara, a perplexed and panicking mother 😰, had to confront her teenage daughter's sudden announcement about her 'sexual orientation'. 

❗️Brother Karim was heartbroken 💔 when his son moved in with a girl he met in college. 

❗️And Abu Laila faced the painful reality 🛟 of his daughter rejecting her faith in Allah.

These are just a few examples of the struggles faced by parents in our community that I have personally come across 😢.

As I listen to these desperate calls from parents, I realise that somewhere along their parenting journey, they sometimes inadvertently neglected or overlooked essential guidance from the Qur'an, Sunnah and the wisdom of our predecessors and elders.

I don't want you to experience the pain and regret that these parents have endured. 

That's why I am reaching out to offer you a unique opportunity to learn how to nurture your child in the best possible way.

Your child is not just your own; they are a child of the Ummah of Muhammad ﷺ.

When you succeed in raising them with love, guidance and wisdom, our entire Ummah benefits. We are a village and it is our collective responsibility to raise our children together, sharing wisdom and supporting one another along the journey.

I believe that by equipping yourself with the knowledge, practices and insights rooted in the teachings of the Qur'an and Sunnah and benefitting from my experience as a mother of four, you can navigate the challenges of parenting and stack the deck in your favour, on your path to raising Believers.

To help you in this mission, I invite you to join me for the upcoming Raising Believers Islamic Parenting Masterclass:
Raisingbelievers.com

Slow and steady wins the race. 
As a wife, mother and homemaker, I decided to continue my studies at a much slower pace, studying part time, so that I might maintain a balance and give my family its due importance.

Alhamdulillah a special day with my family today, the official graduation ceremony for my Masters degree from #SOAS in Islamic Law. I graduated with Distinction, winning the Doreen Hinchcliffe Memorial Prize for Best Overall Student in Islamic Law. Alhamdulillah.

My father got to meet my professor and mentor too: Professor of Laws Mashood Baderin. He is a qualified Barrister and an ‘Alim of Maliki Fiqh. And my daughter and family were with me throughout the day.

It was surreal also to meet Zeinab Badawi who I grew up watching on BBC news and was Master of Ceremonies.

This was my first experience of a Western style university as my previous studies were at seminaries after A-Levels. I enjoyed the challenge and the opportunity to learn to articulate a strong argument, to order my thoughts and bring orthodox Islamic voices to the fore.

There were some challenging moments. Some amazing new friendships and some awakenings regarding the good and bad of academia.
